Actual Answer: Under the Maternity and Parental Leave etc. Regulations 1999, specifically Regulation 10, if an employee on maternity leave is at risk of redundancy, she must be offered any suitable alternative vacancy available before it is offered to other employees, giving her priority for redeployment opportunities. Regarding health and safety, the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999, Regulation 16, mandates employers to perform a specific risk assessment for new or expectant mothers, and if risks are identified and cannot be avoided, the employer must adjust her working conditions or hours, offer suitable alternative work on no less favorable terms, or if no alternative is available, suspend her on full pay. Relevant case law, such as Sefton Borough Council v Wainwright [2014] EWCA Civ 953, confirms the obligation to offer suitable alternative employment to employees on maternity leave before others. Therefore, the employer must conduct a fair and non-discriminatory redundancy process, prioritize the employee for any suitable alternative positions, and address health and safety concerns by performing risk assessments and taking necessary actions to protect the employee.

EXPLANATORY NOTE
(This note is not part of the Regulations)
These Regulations are made in exercise of the powers inserted into the Employment Rights (Northern Ireland) Order 1996 (N.I. 16) (the “1996 Order”) by the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Act (Northern Ireland) 2022 (c. 5).
The Regulations revoke and re-enact the provisions of the Parental Bereavement Leave Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2023 which would otherwise cease to have effect by virtue of Article 251(1A) of the Employment Rights (Northern Ireland) Order 1996.
These Regulations provide for a statutory entitlement for bereaved parents who are employees to take up to two weeks’ leave from their job called parental bereavement leave in the 56 weeks following the death of a child.
Part 2 relates to entitlement to parental bereavement leave. The right to take parental bereavement leave is conferred by regulation 4 which sets out the conditions for entitlement which must be satisfied by the employee in order to take parental bereavement leave. These include substantive requirements, such as the employee falling within the definition of a bereaved parent (in particular, specifying the types of parental relationships in respect of which the new entitlement arises), as well as procedural requirements, such as the employee giving appropriate notices to their employer. Where an employee is entitled to parental bereavement leave under regulation 4 as the result of the death of more than one child, the employee is entitled to parental bereavement leave in respect of each child.
Regulation 5 sets out the number of weeks of parental bereavement leave that are available to a bereaved parent and gives an employee the option of taking either one or two weeks’ parental bereavement leave. The weeks taken as parental bereavement leave do not need to be taken consecutively. It also provides that parental bereavement leave may only be taken within the period of 56 weeks beginning with the date of the child’s death.
Regulation 6 details the notice requirements and other information the bereaved parent must provide to their employer before taking parental bereavement leave. An employee does not need to provide notice in writing to his or her employer, but the length of notice required to book and cancel parental bereavement leave will vary depending on whether the period the employee intends to take as parental bereavement leave falls within 56 days of the child’s death or later. Regulations 7 and 8 respectively set out when an employee’s period of bereavement leave may start and what happens when a period of parental bereavement leave is interrupted by another type of statutory leave under Part 9 of the 1996 Order.
Part 3 contains provisions applicable in relation to the taking of parental bereavement leave. Regulation 9 elaborates on the new Article 112EB of the 1996 Order, by providing that an employee is entitled during his or her absence on leave to the benefit of all of his or her terms and conditions of employment apart from the right to remuneration (excluded by Article 112EB(2)(b)); also that the employee is subject to all of the obligations under those terms and conditions except in so far as they are inconsistent with the right to take parental bereavement leave (the exception appears in Article 112EB(1)(b)). Regulations 10 and 11 provide for an employee’s right to return to work after taking a period of parental bereavement leave, distinguishing the case where the leave was an isolated period of absence from the case where it followed another period of statutory leave. Regulations 12 and 13 provide that an employee entitled to parental bereavement leave is protected from detriment and dismissal attributable to the fact that they took or sought to take parental bereavement leave.
Part 4 contains provisions applicable where an employee has a contractual right to parental bereavement leave, in addition to the statutory right contained within these Regulations.
Part 5 (regulations 16 to 22) contains provisions in respect of the Transitional arrangements that will ensure a continuity of entitlement between the revoked Regulations and current Regulations. This part also contains the revocation of the Parental Bereavement Leave Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2023.
A separate impact assessment has not been prepared for these Regulations. The Regulations are part of a package of legislative measures and the relevant impact assessment is the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Bill impact assessment which was published in April 2020. 2. **Action on Receipt of Report**: Upon notification, the landlord must repair or replace the faulty alarm as soon as reasonably practicable. This is stipulated in regulation 4(c) of the amended regulations.

   - **Document the Issue**: Keep records of all communications and attempts to resolve the matter.

Response:
**Apprentice Wage Rights and Remedies in England**

As an apprentice who has turned 19 and completed their first year, you have specific rights regarding your wages under the National Minimum Wage Act 1998 (as amended) and the National Minimum Wage Regulations 2015.

**Your Rights:**
1. **Minimum Wage Entitlement:** After turning 19 and completing the first year of your apprenticeship, you are entitled to receive at least the National Minimum Wage (NMW) for someone aged 19-20. As of April 2023, this rate is £9.50 per hour.

2. **Apprentice Pay Transition:** Once you reach 19 and have completed your first year, you transition from the apprentice rate to the adult NMW. This means your employer must cease paying the youth development rate.

**Steps if Employer is Non-Compliant:**
1. **Request Documentation:** Obtain written proof of your earnings from your employer. Use tools like the HMRC PAYE calculator to verify compliance.

2. **File a Complaint:** Report any suspected non-compliance to the Employment Relations Agency (ERA) or the Child Labour Unit, especially if under 16.

3. **Seek Advice:**
   - **Citizens Advice Bureau (CAB):** For guidance on your rights and next steps.
   - **Acas:** Offers advisory services for workplace issues.
   - **Trade Union Congress (TUC):** Provides support and can assist with formal actions.

4. **Legal Action:** If necessary, you can take your employer to an Employment Tribunal. Tribunals may order back pay and impose penalties on the employer for non-compliance.

5. **Record-Keeping:** Maintain records of all earnings, including payslips and bank statements, as evidence for any potential disputes or legal actions.

**Important Considerations:**
- Ensure you understand your specific contract terms regarding apprentice pay.
- The NMW rate may be subject to annual reviews, so check the latest figures on the GOV.UK website.

**Conclusion:**
You have the right to receive the correct minimum wage once you meet the age and experience criteria. If your employer is non-compliant, take proactive steps such as seeking advice and filing a complaint to protect your rights.

### Legal Obligations of the Local Authority:
1. **Implementation Requirement**: The local authority is legally required to establish separate food waste collections as mandated by the Environment Act 2021. This requirement aims to promote recycling and reduce waste disposed of in landfill sites.

2. **Deadline Compliance**: There is a legal obligation to meet the specified deadlines set forth in the act. Failure to do so may result in enforcement actions or legal consequences.

3. **Waste Disposal Responsibility**: Local authorities are responsible for ensuring that food waste is collected, processed, and disposed of in an environmentally friendly manner, reducing its impact on public health and the environment.

### Legal Remedies Available to Residents:

4. **Legal Challenges**: In severe cases, residents might consider seeking legal advice from environmental law specialists to explore options for enforcement through the courts.

Local authorities are obligated by the Environment Act 2021 to implement separate food waste collections. Residents concerned about non-compliance can take proactive steps such as reporting issues and engaging with regulatory bodies to ensure adherence to environmental legislation.

If the landlord remains unresponsive, the tenant can contact the local authority's Environmental Health department, which can inspect the property and issue improvement notices. If a tenant in Wales notices issues like severe damp or mold that the landlord has failed to address despite repeated requests, the tenant can take steps to enforce these responsibilities.

1. **Landlord's Obligations**: 
   - The landlord must respond to notifications from the tenant about potential faults, defects, or disrepairs in the property.
   - If the tenant believes an issue is not the landlord's responsibility (such as arising from the tenant's own actions), they may be required to carry out repairs themselves within a reasonable timeframe.

The Additional Learning Needs and Education Tribunal (Wales) Act 2018 provides a strong legal framework to protect the rights of children with special educational needs (SEN) in Wales, ensuring they receive appropriate education and support. Here's how the Act safeguards these rights and the steps parents should take:
How the Act Protects the Child’s Right to Education
                           * Definition of Additional Learning Needs (ALN) (Section 2): The Act defines ALN as a learning difficulty or disability that requires additional learning provision.                            * Individual Development Plans (IDPs) (Section 10): The Act mandates the creation of IDPs for children with ALN. These comprehensive, tailored plans detail the specific support required and are maintained by local authorities or educational institutions, guaranteeing that each child's unique needs are met.
                           * Duties of Local Authorities and Schools (Sections 11 and 14): Local authorities and the governing bodies of maintained schools have a duty to identify children with ALN and make appropriate provisions. They must review these provisions regularly to ensure their effectiveness and adapt them as needed.
                           * Participation and Rights (Section 6): The Act emphasizes involving children and their parents in the decision-making process regarding ALN support. Authorities must also consider the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, reinforcing a rights-based approach.
                           * Access to Information and Advice (Section 9): The Act requires local authorities to provide parents with information and advice on ALN and the available support, empowering them to make informed decisions.
                           * Dispute Resolution and Appeals (Sections 68 and 70): The Act establishes clear mechanisms for resolving disagreements. If parents are unsatisfied with the IDP or support provided, they can use local dispute resolution services. Additionally, they have the right to appeal decisions to the Education Tribunal for Wales.
Steps Parents Should Take to Ensure Their Child Receives Support
                           * Request an Assessment: Parents can request that the local authority assess their child for ALN. Although the Act does not explicitly state this in Section 11, it mandates that authorities and schools must decide if a child has ALN when concerns are raised.
                           * Engage in the IDP Process: Actively participate in the development and review of the IDP. Ensure the IDP reflects the child's current needs and advocate for revisions as needed.
                           * Utilize Available Resources: Make use of the information and advice provided by local authorities as mandated in Section 9. This will help parents understand their rights and the provisions their child is entitled to.
                           * Address Disagreements: If there are concerns about the IDP or the support provided, use the dispute resolution mechanisms outlined in Section 68. For unresolved issues, parents can appeal to the Education Tribunal for Wales as outlined in Section 70.
                           * Regularly Review the IDP: Ensure that the IDP is reviewed regularly, as mandated by the Act, to keep it aligned with the child’s evolving educational needs.
This framework ensures that children with SEN in Wales receive the educational support they require, and parents are empowered to advocate effectively for their child’s rights.

Section 80EA of the Employment Rights Act 1996 (as amended) grants eligible employees the right to take at least two weeks of parental bereavement leave. This leave must be taken within 56 days from the date of the child’s death and applies to the death of a child under 18. Section 80EE extends these rights to cases involving stillbirths after 24 weeks of pregnancy. Employers are obligated to provide this leave, ensuring that eligible employees can take time off without facing any detriment or dismissal related to their leave request. For statutory parental bereavement pay, Section 171ZZ6 of the Social Security Contributions and Benefits Act 1992 (as amended) outlines the entitlement, specifying that the employee must meet certain conditions such as a continuous employment period of at least 26 weeks ending with the "relevant week" (the week immediately before the child’s death) and minimum earnings meeting the lower earnings limit. Section 171ZZ7 adds that employees must give notice to their employer about the weeks for which they seek parental bereavement pay, and employers may require this notice in writing. Regulations under this section may also stipulate further requirements, such as providing evidence of entitlement or conditions for determining continuous employment. In addition to these primary sections, reviewing supporting regulations linked to the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Act 2018 and related guidance is essential for comprehensive compliance. Regulations detail how leave is to be taken, how statutory pay is processed, and additional procedural requirements for both employees and employers.

**Employee Rights:**

Under the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Act 2018, an employee in Scotland is entitled to a certain amount of bereavement leave upon the loss of a child. Key points include:

1. **Eligibility**: The employee must meet specific conditions, such as being a parent or having responsibility for the child's care.
2. **Leave Entitlement**: 
   - 5 working days off in the first year of employment.
   - 25 working days if the employer has been with the company continuously for more than three years.

3. **Payment**: The leave is typically paid at 100% of the employee’s salary, calculated based on their average weekly earnings over the previous 17 weeks. This payment comes from the Social Security system and is deducted through payroll.

2. **Non-Discrimination**: Employees cannot be discriminated against based on their loss.
3. **No Medical Proof Needed**: Unless the employer suspects fraudulent activity, proof of the child’s death isn’t required.
4. **Pay Protection**: Employers must maintain salary levels during the leave period and not reduce other pay-related elements like bonuses or commissions.

**Additional Considerations:**

- The Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Act 2018 applies specifically to those who lose a child after March 25, 2021.
- It’s advisable for employees to consult their HR department or Citizens Advice for personalized guidance.

This duty requires landlords to complete any necessary repairs within a reasonable time after being notified by the tenant or otherwise becoming aware of the need for repairs. Failure to act within a reasonable timeframe constitutes a breach of this duty. If the landlord does not take action, the tenant can apply to the First-tier Tribunal under Section 22 of the Act. This section allows tenants to seek a decision from the Tribunal if the property does not meet the Repairing Standard. The Tribunal can investigate and issue a Repairing Standard Enforcement Order (RSEO) under Section 24, compelling the landlord to carry out the required repairs within a specified timeframe. If the landlord fails to comply with the RSEO, under Section 26, the Tribunal must notify the local authority and may consider imposing a rent relief order to reduce the tenant’s rent. The Tribunal may excuse non-compliance if the landlord demonstrates an inability to comply due to a lack of necessary rights (e.g., access) or if the required work poses a danger to any person. In such cases, the Tribunal must notify the local authority of its findings. The Housing (Scotland) Act 2006 provides tenants with clear mechanisms to address substandard housing conditions and enforce their rights against landlords who fail to fulfill their obligations. These regulations govern the procedures of the First-tier Tribunal for Scotland Housing and Property Chamber, which is responsible for handling cases brought under the Housing (Scotland) Act 2006, including applications related to the Repairing Standard. The regulations ensure that disputes between tenants and landlords are resolved fairly and efficiently. They outline the rules for submitting applications, conducting hearings, issuing decisions, and enforcing orders such as Repairing Standard Enforcement Orders (RSEOs). This procedural framework directly supports tenants in seeking remedies for landlords' failures to meet their legal obligations under the Act.

Under the Domestic Abuse (Protection) (Scotland) Act 2021, what legal protections are available, and what steps should they take?
Actual Answer: Individuals experiencing domestic abuse in Scotland can seek protection through several legal mechanisms. Under the Protection from Harassment Act 1997, they can apply for a Non-Harassment Order, which prohibits the abuser from engaging in threatening or harassing behavior. Additionally, the Matrimonial Homes (Family Protection) (Scotland) Act 1981 allows for an Exclusion Order to remove the abuser from the shared home and prevent them from re-entering. This Act applies not only to married couples but also to cohabitants. The individual should contact the police to report the abuse, as domestic abuse is a criminal offense under the Domestic Abuse (Scotland) Act 2018, which recognizes controlling behavior as abuse. Seeking legal advice from a solicitor experienced in domestic abuse cases is advisable to assist with applications for protective orders, and engaging with support services such as Scottish Women's Aid can provide additional assistance and guidance.
Response:
Under the Domestic Abuse (Protection) (Scotland) Act 2021 and Scottish housing laws, here are the key steps and legal protections available for an individual experiencing domestic abuse in a shared tenancy:

### Key Steps and Legal Protections

1. **Seek Immediate Assistance:**
   - Contact a lawyer specializing in family or property law to understand your rights and options under both the Domestic Abuse Act and tenancy agreements.

2. **Inform Your Landlord:**
   - Provide written notice to your landlord detailing instances of domestic abuse, including any threats or violence that make living together unsafe.
   - Attach evidence, such as police reports or protective orders, to support your claim.

3. **Apply for a Protective Order:**
   - File a petition with the court under the Domestic Abuse (Protection) (Scotland) Act 2021 to obtain a non-harassment order, which can prevent the abuser from entering the property and force them to leave if necessary.

4. **Termination of Tenancy:**
   - If your tenancy agreement allows for termination due to domestic abuse, you may be able to end it. Check your lease terms or consult your lawyer on this possibility.
   - The landlord may have a legal obligation to assist with eviction, especially if the abuser is causing a disturbance.

5. **Housing Options:**
   - Explore temporary housing options through local authorities, charities, or support organizations like Shelter Scotland.
   - Consider seeking emergency accommodation if you feel unsafe at home.

6. **Secure Your Residence:**
   - Remove personal belongings and secure them in a safe location. If possible, move them temporarily to another address.

7. **Seek Support Services:**
   - Access counseling services or support groups to help with emotional recovery.
   - Utilize resources from the Scottish government or non-profits for victims of abuse.

8. **Consider Court Orders:**
   - The court may issue an order compelling the abuser to leave the property, though this process can take time and may require evidence of abuse.

9. **Use Supportive Charities:**
   - Engage with organizations like Scottish Women's Aid or Shelter Scotland for guidance and assistance in finding safe housing.

### Important Considerations
- **Evidence:** Collect and present any evidence of domestic abuse to strengthen your case, such as police reports or witness statements.
- **Timeline:** Eviction processes can vary, so consult a lawyer for advice on how long the process might take.
- **Emotional Safety:** Prioritize your emotional well-being by securing safe housing and ensuring your personal items are protected.

By taking these steps, you can assert your legal rights and work towards a safer living environment. Remember to seek professional advice from trusted legal or support organizations to navigate this challenging situation effectively.

Actual Answer:
Under the Parental Bereavement Leave and Pay Act (NothernIreland) 2022, an employee in NothernIreland who has recently lost a child is entitled to bereavement leave, and if they meet certain criteria, they may also be eligible for bereavement pay. Article 112EA(1)-(3) defines a "bereaved parent" as an employee who meets specified relationship conditions with the deceased child, which may include a caregiving role before the child’s death. Employees who lose a child under 18, or experience a stillbirth after 24 weeks of pregnancy, are entitled to at least two weeks of bereavement leave under Article 112EA(5). This leave can be taken either as a single two-week block or in two separate one-week periods. According to Article 112EA(6), this leave must be taken within at least 56 days (eight weeks) from the date of the child’s death, providing flexibility within that period.
If an employee loses more than one child, Article 112EA(7) entitles them to bereavement leave for each child. Article 112EB outlines rights during and after bereavement leave, specifying that employees on leave retain most employment terms and conditions (excluding remuneration). According to Article 112EB(1)(a)-(c), employees are entitled to return to their original or an equivalent job after bereavement leave. Furthermore, Article 112EB(3) provides that if bereavement leave coincides with other types of parental leave (such as maternity or paternity leave), the right to return applies across the entire period of absence.
To access bereavement leave, Article 112ED(a) requires employees to notify their employer as soon as reasonably practicable, specifying the intended dates for leave. Employers are obligated to grant this leave and cannot delay or refuse it. If the employee is also eligible for statutory bereavement pay, they must provide notice and any required documentation as directed under Articles 112ED(a) and (c).

(This note is not part of the Regulations)
These Regulations are made in exercise of the powers inserted into the Employment Rights (Northern Ireland) Order 1996 (N.I. 16) (the “1996 Order”) by the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Act (Northern Ireland) 2022 (c. 5).
The Regulations revoke and re-enact the provisions of the Parental Bereavement Leave Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2023 which would otherwise cease to have effect by virtue of Article 251(1A) of the Employment Rights (Northern Ireland) Order 1996.
These Regulations provide for a statutory entitlement for bereaved parents who are employees to take up to two weeks’ leave from their job called parental bereavement leave in the 56 weeks following the death of a child.
Part 2 relates to entitlement to parental bereavement leave. The right to take parental bereavement leave is conferred by regulation 4 which sets out the conditions for entitlement which must be satisfied by the employee in order to take parental bereavement leave. These include substantive requirements, such as the employee falling within the definition of a bereaved parent (in particular, specifying the types of parental relationships in respect of which the new entitlement arises), as well as procedural requirements, such as the employee giving appropriate notices to their employer. Where an employee is entitled to parental bereavement leave under regulation 4 as the result of the death of more than one child, the employee is entitled to parental bereavement leave in respect of each child.
Regulation 5 sets out the number of weeks of parental bereavement leave that are available to a bereaved parent and gives an employee the option of taking either one or two weeks’ parental bereavement leave. The weeks taken as parental bereavement leave do not need to be taken consecutively. It also provides that parental bereavement leave may only be taken within the period of 56 weeks beginning with the date of the child’s death.
Regulation 6 details the notice requirements and other information the bereaved parent must provide to their employer before taking parental bereavement leave. An employee does not need to provide notice in writing to his or her employer, but the length of notice required to book and cancel parental bereavement leave will vary depending on whether the period the employee intends to take as parental bereavement leave falls within 56 days of the child’s death or later. Regulations 7 and 8 respectively set out when an employee’s period of bereavement leave may start and what happens when a period of parental bereavement leave is interrupted by another type of statutory leave under Part 9 of the 1996 Order.
Part 3 contains provisions applicable in relation to the taking of parental bereavement leave. Regulation 9 elaborates on the new Article 112EB of the 1996 Order, by providing that an employee is entitled during his or her absence on leave to the benefit of all of his or her terms and conditions of employment apart from the right to remuneration (excluded by Article 112EB(2)(b)); also that the employee is subject to all of the obligations under those terms and conditions except in so far as they are inconsistent with the right to take parental bereavement leave (the exception appears in Article 112EB(1)(b)). Regulations 10 and 11 provide for an employee’s right to return to work after taking a period of parental bereavement leave, distinguishing the case where the leave was an isolated period of absence from the case where it followed another period of statutory leave. Regulations 12 and 13 provide that an employee entitled to parental bereavement leave is protected from detriment and dismissal attributable to the fact that they took or sought to take parental bereavement leave.
Part 4 contains provisions applicable where an employee has a contractual right to parental bereavement leave, in addition to the statutory right contained within these Regulations.
Part 5 (regulations 16 to 22) contains provisions in respect of the Transitional arrangements that will ensure a continuity of entitlement between the revoked Regulations and current Regulations. This part also contains the revocation of the Parental Bereavement Leave Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2023.
A separate impact assessment has not been prepared for these Regulations. The Regulations are part of a package of legislative measures and the relevant impact assessment is the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Bill impact assessment which was published in April 2020. Response:
**Legal Protections Under the Stalking Act (Northern Ireland) 2022**

An individual in Northern Ireland experiencing harassment and stalking by an ex-partner can avail several legal protections under the Stalking Act (2022). These include:

1. **Stalking Protection Orders (SPOs):** Introduced in October 2023, SPOs allow for early intervention by police to address stalking behaviors before they escalate. They can be applied pre-conviction, providing a range of protective measures such as no-contact orders and monitoring of communications.

2. **Civil Remedies:** The individual may pursue civil injunctions or orders of protection if criminal proceedings are not expeditious. These can include restraining orders to prevent further harassment and require the harasser to engage in counseling or treatment programs.

3. **Existing Legislation:** The Protection from Harassment Act 1997 forms the basis for Northern Ireland's anti-stalking laws, incorporating provisions on harassment and stalking. This underpins the new Stalking Act, enhancing protections with more tailored measures.

**Steps to Take for Safety**

1. **Report Incidents to Police:** Immediate action is crucial. Contact the police to report all instances of harassment and stalking. Provide evidence such as texts, emails, or physical proof to support your case.

2. **Apply for a Stalking Protection Order:** To obtain an SPO, you must provide evidence of harassment to the courts. Legal representation can assist in navigating this process, ensuring your rights are protected.

3. **Seek Legal Advice:** Consult with a lawyer specializing in domestic abuse or family law. They can guide you through the legal framework and advise on the best course of action, whether criminal or civil.

4. **Consider Civil Actions:** If criminal proceedings are slow, consider seeking a civil injunction or order of protection. This can provide immediate relief while criminal charges are processed.

5. **Utilize Support Services:** Engage with organizations like the Women and Girls Network NI for emotional support and guidance on safety measures and legal processes.

6. **Document Incidents:** Keep detailed records of all interactions, including dates, times, locations, and any evidence collected. This documentation is vital for both criminal and civil cases.

By taking these steps, you can assert your rights and work towards a safer environment, supported by both legal and support networks.
